metadata.title: Effect of Zn addition on structural, magnetic properties and anti-structural modeling of magnesium-nickel nano ferrites

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Chemistry and Physics
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/matchemphys
Effect of Zn addition on structural, magnetic properties and anti-structural modeling of magnesium-nickel nano ferrites P. Tiwaria,b, R. Vermaa, S.N. Kanea,∗, Tetiana Tatarchukc,d, F. Mazaleyrate a Magnetic Materials Laboratory, School of Physics, D. A. University, Khandwa Road Campus, Indore, 452001, India b Department of Physics, Prestige Institute of Engineering and Management and Research, Indore, 452010, India c Department of Chemistry, Vasyl Stefanyk Precarpathian National University, 57, Shevchenko Str., Ivano-Frankivsk, 76018, Ukraine d Educational and Scientific Center of Materials Science and Nanotechnology, Vasyl Stefanyk Precarpathian National University, Ivano-Frankivsk, Ukraine e SATIE, ENS Cachan, UMR CNRS 8029, Universite Paris-Saclay, 61 Avenue President Wilson, 94235, Cachan, France
H I G H L I G H T S
• Zn addition induced changes in properties of Mg-Ni nano ferrites are reported. • XRD confirms formation of cubic ferrite with grain diameter between 40–42 nm. • Addition of Zn alters cation distribution and thus structural, magnetic properties. • With Zn content, Hc decreases linearly and Ms shows non-monotonic variation. • Surface active centers for Mg0.7xNi0.3ZnxFe2O4 are discussed for the first time.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Ferrites Cation distribution XRD Magnetic properties Antistructural modeling
A B S T R A C T
Effect of Zn addition in Mg0.7−xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 (with x = 0.0–0.7) prepared via solution combustion technique have been studied in terms of structural, magnetic properties, cationic distribution and surface morphology. Xray diffraction (XRD) (with crystallite size (D) < 42.89 nm) and Fourier transmission infrared (FTIR) measurements validate the formation of spinel ferrite phase. Cationic distribution of Mg-Ni-Zn ferrite has been estimated by analyzing the X-ray intensity of the (220), (400), (440) and (422) reflections. The FTIR study between 375 and 1000 cm−1 exhibit two absorption bands corresponding to tetrahedral (541-562 cm−1) and octahedral sites (423-430 cm−1) of Mg0.7-xNi0.3ZnxFe2O4 spinel structure. A new approach in solid state chemistry for explaining the surface active centers for Mg0.7-xNi0.3ZnxFe2O4 system is also discussed for the first time. Coercivity (Hc) decreases linearly with Zn content. Saturation magnetization (Ms) increases for lower Zn content (0.00 ≤ x ≤ 0.3) and reduces for higher Zn content (0.3 < x ≤ 0.7), ascribed to the distribution of cations at A, B site.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matchemphys.2019.02.030 Received 22 July 2018; Received in revised form 16 January 2019; Accepted 9 February 2019
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: priyanka.tiwari91092@gmail.com (P. Tiwari), roshnikedar@gmail.com (R. Verma), kane_sn@yahoo.com (S.N. Kane),
tatarchuk.tetyana@gmail.com (T. Tatarchuk), frederic.mazaleyrat@ens-paris-saclay.fr (F. Mazaleyrat).
Materials Chemistry and Physics 229 (2019) 78–86
0254-0584/ © 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Spinel ferrites (SF) are Fe containing oxides (with two crystallographic sites: tetrahedral - (A), octahedral - [B] site), which are mostly encountered system due to their extensive scope of applications in electrical devices [1–3], as catalysts [4], as humidity sensors [5], drug delivery [6], as O2 carriers in chemical looping [7] and water treatment [8]. This coupled with their attractive physical, chemical, structural, magnetic properties, low cost, environmentally gentle and high natural profusion [9] makes SF a versatile material. These properties of SF nano particles are different from their bulk counter part because of their sizes, cation distribution, and stoichiometry [10,11]. When particle size lies in nano regime the mostly affected property of SF is the magnetic property (especially high initial permeability, essential for reducing the number layer of multi layer chip inductors ‘MLCI’, minimizing the inter-layer capacitance), which depends on cationic distribution at A, B site. Cationic migration between A, B site has substantial effect on saturation magnetization (MS), magnetic moment and exchange coupling between A-A, A-B and B-B sites [12–14].
Cationic distribution parameter remains an important tool for controlling magnetic properties of Fe-containing spinels. Such fine-tuning can be done just by the selective substitution of different types (Zn2+, Ni2+,Mg2+, Cu2+, Fe3+) and amount of ions at available interstitial sites (A, B). According to occupancy of divalent/trivalent cations at A, B site, the spinel arrangement would change from normal to inverse. 100% occupancy of divalent metal ions at A, or B site produces normal or inverse spinel structure respectively. Mixed/disordered spinel structure is produced when divalent metal ions are there on at A, B sites. Cationic distribution depends on synthesis methods and synthesis parameters [15]. SF has been rigorously synthesized by several methods such as solid-state reaction [16], conventional ceramic technique [17], sol-gel auto-combustion [18], hydrothermal synthesis [19], co-precipitation [20] and micro-emulsion [21]. Among all the available methods, sol-gel auto-combustion method has emerged as an extremely potential method to prepare nano-scale powders [22]. This preparation method is easy, harmless, cost-effective and less time consuming. Solgel auto-combustion process do not needs any external heat sources and provides spontaneous combustion between the metal nitrates (oxidizer) and organic fuels (reducing agents) e. g. - citric acid, urea, polyvinyl alcohol, alanine etc. [23]. Dopants can be placed in the final product very easily; it requires simple equipment, low processing time and low external energy consumption [24]. The above cited preparation methods [16–21] not only influences cationic distribution but also has considerable effect on structural, magnetic properties of SF [25,26].
One of the most appealing SF - magnesium ferrite (MgFe2O4) has a partial inverse cubic spinel structure (Mg2+1-δFe3+δ )A [Mg2+δ Fe3+2-δ ]B O2-4 , where δ is the degree of inversion. Ni ferrite (NiFe2O4) possess an inverse spinel structure: (Fe3+δ )A [Ni2+δ Fe3+2-δ ]B O2-4 and Zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) has a normal spinel arrangement (Zn2+δ )A [Fe3+2 ]B O2-4 [27]. Thus, Zn doped Mg-Ni ferrite will have a mixed spinel arrangement. Among other SF, Mg-Ni-Zn ferrite have gain substantial attention by the researchers because of their wide-ranging and excellent properties [28–32], which can be useful in a different applications such as microwave absorption, transformers, magnetic storage and, high frequency applications [28,29,32–35]. Structural, magnetic properties of SF can be change by substitution of nonmagnetic cations: Mg, Zn [36–40]. But the study of Zn substituted Mg-Ni ferrite is not enough [28–32].
Although we report similar compositions as reported in ref. 28–32, it is worth noting that Zn ions significantly influence the structure, magnetic properties of magnesium-nickel based ferrites. Minor changes in composition can be effectively utilized to induce structural changes and, thus affecting magnetic properties, to be able to make use of them for future applications.
The replacement of a non-magnetic cation (Mg) by another nonmagnetic cation (Zn) will produce some noticeable effects on structural,
magnetic properties of Mg0.7−xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 spinel ferrite system. Hence, it is worth studying the structural, magnetic properties of Mg0.7xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 spinel ferrite as the intricate characteristics resulting from the structure and cationic distribution of Zn, Ni, Mg ferrite might combine to furnish assorted properties.
Therefore, the present study communicates the magnetic, structural and cationic distribution of Zn2+ substituted magnesium-nickel ferrite with x ranging from 0.0 to 0.7 in steps of 0.1 synthesized using solution combustion method.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: All precursors used in this study (Zinc Nitrate Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Nickel Acetate Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O, Magnesium Acetate (CH3COO)2Mg·4H2O and Ferric Nitrate Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Citric Acid (HOOCCH2)2C(OH)COOH, Ammonia solution (25%) NH3·H2O), were of analytical grade and were used for the synthesis of Mg0.7xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 (x = 0.0–0.7) spinel ferrites.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material synthesis
sections.text:
Fig. 1 depicts schematic for synthesizing Mg0.7−xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 ferrites by solution combustion method. Stoichiometric amount of nitrate/acetate pre-cursors were mixed and the citric acid was added (in the molar ratio 1:1). Citric acid has triple role: it acts as a chelating reagent, reductant, and as a fuel The solution combustion technique is easy, low-cost, synthesis is carried out at relatively lower temperatures (∼110 °C) is an energy efficient synthesis process with diminishing thermal costs and allows to prepare nanoscale powders [41]. All precursors were dissolved in the deionized water in stoichiometric ratio and then ammonia solution (NH4OH) was added for rising pH up to 7 under continuous stirring. Now the solution was heated at 120 °C in air until brown fluffy powder was formed. Next step was the annealing of as-burnt powder at 500 °C for 3 h in air. The chemical reaction during the process can be described as follows:

sections.heading: 2.3. Material characterizations
sections.text: Room temperature structural properties of annealed powders were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Cu-Kα radiation (wavelength ‘λ’ = 0.1541 nm) in θ-2θ configuration (step size of 0.02°, 1.14°/min), equipped by a fast counting Bruker LynxEye detector, with Silicon strip technology. Surface morphology of Mg-Ni-Zn ferrite samples were evaluated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-5600). The Fourier transmission infrared (FTIR) measurements (in absorption mode) in the studied samples were carried out (contained within a KBr matrix) by Perkin-Elemer FTIR spectrometer in a region of wave number from 375 to 1000 cm−1. Room temperature magnetization studies were done using a vibrating sample magnetometer (Lake Shore 7310) with a maximum applied field (Hmax.) of ± 1.9 T. The saturation magnetization (Ms) and coercivity (Hc) as magnetic parameters have been determined from hysteresis loops.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structural properties
sections.text:
Rietveld refinement (done via MAUD (Material Analysis Using Diffraction) software [42]) XRD patterns of Zn2+ doped annealed 500 °C/3hrs Mg0.7-xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 (x = 0.0–0.7) ferrite system is depicted in Fig. 2. XRD confirms the single phase spinel structure of MgNi-Zn ferrite, signifying the cations solubility within their individual lattice sites. Only for the sample x = 0.0, secondary phase of Fe2O3 (weight % = 14.769292, a = 0.5035 nm, c = 1.3765 nm) is detected. It is of value to note that Fe2O3 peak is common in Ni rich compounds, as was also observed in earlier reports [18,43]. Formation of minor Fe2O3 phase is endorsable to partial decomposition of ferrite phase [44].
Structural parameters: experimental lattice parameter (aexp.), hopping length at A (LA a0.25 3= )and B (LB a0.25 2= ) site, crystallite size (D), X-ray density (ρXRD) and specific surface area (S) of Mg0.7xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 samples were calculated as depicted in Refs. [13,18,45] and are specified in Table 1. Observed changes in aexp. LA, LB ascribable to the difference in ionic radii of Zn2+ (0.060 nm) and Mg2+
(0.057 nm) ions. Non-monotonic variation in experimental lattice parameter and hopping length at A (LA) and B (LB) sites can be due to the close values of ionic radii of Zn2+ and Mg2+ ions. The observed increase in X-ray density values of Zn doped Mg-Ni ferrite system (from Table 1) can be attributed to replacement of an ion with lower atomic mass Mg (24.312 g mol−1) by an ion with higher atomic mass Zn (65.37 g mol−1). Crystallite size (D) for annealed system shows discontinuous grain growth [32] because of the inhomogeneous driving
force of the grain boundary movement [46]. The different parameters: pH, temperature, initial concentration of the precursors, site preferences, electronic configuration of cations etc have impact on the grain growth. The non-monotonic behavior of D with increasing Zn concentration may be also due to reaction condition, which initially favored the particle growth and when Zn content is increased further, the creation of new nuclei occurs without increasing particle size. At higher Zn content (0.5–0.7), D decreases, attributed to different dry gel formation time. High specific surface areas (S) of particles are tremendously important for assorted catalytic processes. As is known that high values of surface areas provide small particle sizes. As observed from Table 1 the specific surface area of Zn-Ni-Mg-Cu ferrite system initially decreases upto x = 0.3, increases for x = 0.4 and again decreases thereafter. Increase and decrease of S can be attributed to decrease and increase of D respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2. Cationic distribution
sections.text:
Cationic distribution of Mg-Ni-Zn samples was determined by analyzing the XRD pattern, applying Bertaut method [47–50] (temperature factor was not considered). Distribution of cations of the studied mixed ferrites was calculated using XRD intensities were reported earlier in many reports [18,31,51–55]. XRD intensity depends on the atomic position in spinel unit cell whereas XRD peak position relies on size, shape of unit cell. This method uses following pair of reflections: (400), (422) and (220), (400), according to expression: I
I I I hkl obs
h k l obs
hkl cal
h k l cal= . Where,
Ihklobs and Ihklcal are respectively the observed and estimated intensities for the reflection (hkl). These ratios were evaluated for numerous grouping of cationic distribution at (A), [B] sites as described in Ref. [50]. The finest cationic distribution among A, B sites for which theoretical, experimental lattice parameter agree clearly, were taken. Cationic distribution of Mg0.7-xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 spinel ferrite, inversion parameter (δ), oxygen positional parameter ( )u m43 , experimental, theoretical lattice parameters (aexp., ath.) are depicted in Table 2. Perusal of Table 2 shows that, for low, high Zn content, samples show inverse structure and in between it shows mixed structure. It is of value to note that, Zn occupies tetrahedral A site, although in present studies, it located on B site i. e. showing-up a non-equilibrium cation distribution, cationic inversion (as observed in the present studies) ascribable to the presence of oxygen vacancies, known to affect cationic distribution, leading to spin disorder, and thus affecting magnetic properties [56].
Close matching of aexp., ath suggest an appropriate redistribution of cations among A, B site. The annealed samples posses a partially inverted/mixed spinel structure because in nano range the power of ligands decreases which makes the divalent zinc ions free to locate at B site. The partial migration of zinc ions from A to B site is accompanied by a simultaneous migration of the ferric ions from B to A site, resulting in a mixed spinel structure of Mg0.7-xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 spinel ferrite [56]. Distribution of cations in the present system shows the same trend as observed earlier [18,51,52,57].
Using the obtained cationic distribution A, B-site ionic radii (rA, rB) were calculated using the relations [57]:
r C Zn rZn C Ni rNi C Mg rMg C Fe rFe( ) ( ) ( ) ( )A A A A A= + + + (1a)
r C Zn rZn C Ni rNi C Mg rMg C Fe rFe[( ) ( ) ( ) ( )]/2B B B B B= + + + (1b)
Where CA and CB = ionic concentration of cations (Zn2+, Ni2+, Mg2+, Fe3+) at A, B sites respectively. Ionic radius of cations (rZn2+, rNi2+, rMg2+, rFe2+) used in calculation is taken from the work of Shannon [58]. For a better understanding of Mg-Ni-Zn ferrite spinel structure tetrahedral, octahedral bond length (RA, RB), anionic parameter (u m43 ) and shared tetrahedral/octahedral edge length (dAE, dBE) were also calculated. Oxygen (anion) parameter (u m43 ) is calculated using rA and aexp. values via the expression [53]:
u r R a ( ) ( 3 ) 1 4 m A o4̄3 exp = + × +
(2)
Oxygen parameter represents the movement of O2− ion due to substitution of Ni2+ cation at A site. u m43 parameter reflect modification of the spinel structure to adjust differences in the radius ratio of the cation in A, B sites. Values of u m43 parameter calculated for different compositions ranges between 0.3787 and 0.3810. For an ideal cubic closed packed spinel structure u 0.375idealm43 = [53]. The literature reports the value of u to be greater than 0.375 for most of the spinel ferrites [18,51,52], is ascribable to small dislocation of O2− ions of A site in [111] direction to adjust A cations, which are larger in size than the perfect space permitted by the closed-packed oxygen [53]. The calculated u m43 parameter values are higher than the ideal value (u 0.375idealm43 = ) for entire Mg0.7-xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 nano-ferrite revealing distortion in spinel structure. u m43 and aexp. values were also utilized in the calculation of other cation distribution parameters: dAE, dBE, RA and RB using the relations [55]:

(3d)
A correlation between ionic radii of tetrahedral site (rA), oxygen parameter (u m43 ), shared tetrahedral edge (dAE) and tetrahedral bond length (RA) has been established in Fig. 3 (a). It is observed from Fig. 3 (a) that with increase in rA, u m43 parameter, shared tetrahedral edge and tetrahedral bond length increases. As ionic radii of tetrahedral ions increases the tetrahedral site will expand and anions associated with Asites will shift away from the tetrahedrally coordinated A-site cations.
Such results increase in u parameter, distance between unshared anions (dAE) and the tetrahedral bond length (RA). Similarly, the correlation between ionic radii of B-site (rB), oxygen parameter (u m43 ), shared octahedral edge (dBE) and octahedral bond length (RB) is also premeditated in Fig. 3 (b). The variation of oxygen positional parameter, shared octahedral edge and octahedral bond length has been studied as a function of ionic radii of B-site. As rB increases dBE and RB increases but u m43 parameter decreases. When rB increases, the anions will move away from the octahedral site so, increasing the distance between octahedral cation-anion (RB) and the distance between the “shared anions (dBE). Increase in rB affects on the anions associated with B site which will move towards tetrahedral site, resulting a decrease in the u m43 parameter, as u m43 is the value which represents the displacement of tetrahedral oxygen.

sections.heading: 3.3. Antistructural modeling
sections.text:
Antistructural modeling helps to know the impact of the surface defect's nature onto different processes [59–63]. In order to describe the types of the surface defects on the basis of antistructural model, the superposition of the crystal structure with spinel antistructure V V V" [ ] ( )A B O2 4•• have been used, where V "A - negatively charged cationic vacancy in tetrahedral (A) position, VB - negatively charged cationic vacancy in octahedral (B) position, VO•• - positively charged anionic vacancy in oxygen position. In the Kröger–Vink notation '', ''', and ●● corresponds to the electronic charge of the species in regarding to the sites in the spinel lattice. So each cation from A-site interacts with tetrahedral cationic vacancy V "A, each cation from B-site interacts with octahedral cationic vacancy VB , and oxygen anions interact with anionic vacancy VO••. Detail explanation of the interaction between metal

where 0.00 ≤ x ≤ 0.70; 0.00 ≤ y ≤ 0.24, 0.00 ≤ z ≤ 0.25 (the range of values x and y were calculated on the basis of Rietvield refinement). Thus, superposition of spinel antistructure and chemical formulas of Zndoped Mg-Ni ferrites gives us new information about the nature of the surface active centers (Table 3).
It can be seen from Fig. 4 that the concentration of positively charged ferric ions in tetrahedral (A) sites FeA• versus zinc ions content first decreases (upto x = 0.4) and then increases (for x = 0.5–0.7). For octahedral sites there are three kinds of active centers: MgB, NiB, and ZnB. They have different dependence of their concentration on Zn content values (x). For example, the concentration of ZnB increases rectilinear, while the NiB concentration are still almost constant (in the range from 0.30 to 0.20) except for sample with x = 0.6 (where the NiB concentration has lowest value 0.05 mol). Concerning of MgB, its concentration decreases from 0.7 (sample with x = 0.0) to 0.05 (sample with x = 0.6). In the sample with x = 0.5 all magnesium cations are
situated only in the A-positions, so there are no active centers MgB in Mg Zn Ni Fe O0.2 2 0.5 2 0.3 2 2.0 3 4 2+ + + + .
Crystalloquasichemical formulas (Table 3) demonstrates us new information about surface-active centers. MgA2+, NiA2+ and FeB3+ cations will not be active centers in any chemical reactions because they have an effective zero charge, while FeA3+, MgB2+, NiB2+ and ZnB2+ will be active centers in the catalysis, adsorption or other processes in gaseous or liquid environments.

sections.heading: 3.4. SEM
sections.text:
SEM images for the composition x = 0.0, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7 shown in Fig. 5 depicts difference in surface morphology with particle agglom-
eration with diverse shapes and sizes. This difference in the SEM images signifies that the percentage of different cations: Ni, Zn, Mg play an imperative role in the microstructure of annealed spinel ferrite. However, due to low resolution of the images, no definitive conclusion can be drawn from them.

sections.heading: 3.5. FTIR measurements
sections.text:
The IR spectra of the Mg0.7-xNi0.3ZnxFe2O4 annealed system is shown in Fig. 6 and the band positions are presented in Table 4. There are two absorption bands in the frequency range 375–1000 cm−1 which are corresponds to the main characteristic bands of spinel crystal lattice [64,65]: the first one ν1 is in the range 541–562 cm−1 and the second one ν2 is in the range 423–430 cm−1. Remaining weak absorption bands near 650 cm−1 appear in some cases, as a shoulder to the main bands [65]. We have attributed these bands to the lattice vibrations having tetrahedral symmetry. They are caused by the atomic displacements around the tetrahedral metal ions. It is known [66,67] that the band ν1 and ν2 are due to the vibrations of the MeA-O and MeB-O complexes respectively. The small shift in band positions for Mg-Zn-Ni ferrites is observed as function of Zn content (x) (Table 4) and it may be caused by differences in the ionic distances FeB-O and FeA-O, which are equal 0.199 nm and 0.189 nm respectively [68]. This reason can also
(4)
cause the stronger covalent bonding of Fe3+ ions at the tetrahedral sites than at the octahedral sites.
The force constant (K) estimated from FTIR data and calculated from formulae suggested in the literature [68–71]:

µ m m m m kg1.6605 10 [ ]1 2 1 2 27= + (7)
where m1 is the weighted average atomic mass of the tetrahedral or octahedral cations, while m2 is the atomic mass of the Oxygen (i.e.
15.999 amu). The estimated values of force constants for tetrahedral, octahedral
sites are listed in the Table 4 and the changing of force constants versus tetrahedral, octahedral bond lengths is given in Fig. 7 (a) and Fig. 7 (b) respectively. As mentioned in Refs. [72,73] the force constants are
inversely proportional to bond lengths. The force constant for tetrahedral site is found to decrease with RA as shown in Fig. 7 (a) that suggests weakening of inter-atomic bonding, while the force constants KO is found to increase with RB as shown in Fig. 7 (b) that suggests strengthening of inter-atomic bonding.
Debye temperature is an essential parameter to study lattice vibrations [68]. The Debye temperature (θD) for Mg-Zn-Ni ferrite nanospinels was obtained by using the next relation [71,72]:
hc kD av B =
(8)
where h is Plank constant (h = 6.626 × 10−34 J s), kB is Boltzman constant (kB = 1.3806 × 10−23 J K−1), c is velocity of light (c = 2.99 × 1010 cm s−1) and νav is average wave number of bands (cm−1).
The values of θD for Mg-Zn-Ni ferrite samples are described in Table 4. With increasing zinc content θD first increases from 706.7 K (for x = 0.0) to 710.9 K (for x = 0.1), and after that decreases up to
695.0 K (for x = 0.7). It can be linked to decrease in wave number of the peak usually attributed to Me-O bond vibration in the tetrahedral site. The observed decrease in θD (Table 4) with zinc concentration suggests enhancement of the lattice vibrations due to Zn-substitution. The Debye temperature determined from FT-IR spectra are in good agreement with reported in the literature [68,74].

sections.heading: 3.6. Magnetic measurements
sections.text:
Table 5 depicts the Saturation magnetization (Ms), Coercivity (Hc), and anisotropy constant (K1) for the studied samples. Fig. 8 (a) shows hysteresis loops of the Mg-Zn-Ni ferrites, taken at room temperature. Saturation magnetization (Ms) of the studied samples is determined by drawing M vs. 1/H curve, extrapolating data to 1/H = 0 [14] (Fig. 8 (a) inset) as samples are not saturated even at Hmax. of 1.9 T. The variation of magnetic parameters: coercivity (Hc) and saturation magnetization (Ms) with Zn content is illustrated in Fig. 8 (b). The coercivity of Mg-NiZn ferrite depends on magneto-crystalline anisotropy constant (K1). When Mg2+ ions are replaced by Zn2+ ions, magneto-crystalline anisotropy decreases because the anisotropy constant value of magnesium ferrite is greater than zinc ferrite [13] and hence, Hc decreases, consistent with obtained magneto-crystalline anisotropy constant (K1) values. In Fig. 8 (variation of Hc with Zn content), slope (numerically shows the ratio of the change in y i. e. Hc compared to the change in x i. e. Zn content) indicates a clear relationship between the variable plotted on x and y [here Hc (y) and Zn content (x)], means one affects the other in a meaningful way i. e. upon changing Zn content, shows Hc variation with changes in Zn-content. Perusal of Fig. 8 (b) also depicts variation of Ms with Zn content. Magnetization of Zn-Ni-Mg spinel ferrite is influenced by both extrinsic and inherent parameters such as magnetocrystalline anisotropy constant, grain size, site occupancy of cations and exchange interactions. Fluctuation in grain size also influences the magnetization due to domain wall movement under the action of magnetic field. Saturation magnetization of Mg0.7-xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 (x = 0.0–0.7) ferrite system initially enhances with Ni content upto x = 0.3, then decreases upto x = 0.7, accredited to the occupation of cations as also explained earlier in Refs. [18,51–55]. Magnetization of Zn-Ni-Mg ferrite mainly resides on the Ni2+ (2μB) and Fe3+ (5μB) ions because Zn2+, Mg2+ ions are diamagnetic with 0 magnetic moment. With increasing zinc content up to x = 0.3, Zn2+ ions forces ferric ions to migrate from A to B site of spinel lattice. Thus, the concentration of ferric ions on B site increases which in turn increases magnetic moment of B-sublattice (MB) and decreases magnetic moment of A-sublattice (MA) and therefore, the magnetization increases. For 0.3 < x ≤ 0.7, the concentration of octahedral ferric ions decreases results in decreaseasing magnetic moment of octahedral sublattice (MB) and increases magnetic moment of tetrahedral sublattice (MA) and therefore, the resulting magnetization decreases. Highest value of magnetization (57.55 Am2 kg−1) is obtained for x = 0.3. The obtained values of Hc and Ms are consistent with reported literature [29,31]. As explained earlier in section 3.2, that presence of non-equilibrium cation distribution, cationic (ascribable to the presence of oxygen vacancies), leads to spin
disorder, and will have effect on magnetic properties, as observed in Table 5 and Fig. 8, where it is clearly observed that variation in Zn concentration shows considerable changes in both Hc and Ms, thus minor changes in Zn-content induced structural changes can be effectively utilized to tune magnetic properties, for future applications. It is worth noting that, a x (Zn content) increases, up to x = 0.4, we obtain moderate Hc values (∼75.4 Oe) with highest Ms (56.9 Am2/kg) i. e. best soft magnetic properties were observed. With an aim to get even better soft magnetic behavior (Higher Ms, lower Hc), x (Zn content) was further increased and it was observed that there is a rapid decrease of Ms, although minor changes were observed in Hc (as can be seen in Fig. 8 (b). Thus, Zn content was varied only up to 0.7, for obtaining optimal soft magnetic behavior.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Zn substitution induced changes in structural, magnetic properties, morphology, and cationic distribution of annealing Zn-Ni-Mg ferrite is reported in this paper. X-ray diffraction pattern of annealed (500 °C/ 3hrs) Mg0.7-xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 ferrite with x = 0.0–0.7, synthesized by solution combustion technique gives a clear indication of formation of cubic spinel phase with crystallite size (D) ranging: 40.06–42.89 nm. Variation of aexp., ath., and hopping length for A, B-site (LA, LB) with Zn substitution is endorsed to difference in ionic radii of Zn2+, Ni2+ ions. Zn substitution induced changes in cation distribution on A, B site in Mg0.7xZnxNi0.3Fe2O4 ferrite have significant effect on u parameter, dAE, dBE, RA and RB. SEM images clearly show particle agglomerates. The force constants (KT, KO) for A, B site respectively calculated from IR band frequencies shows that KT decreases with tetrahedral bond length and KO increases with octahedral bond length. The new approach antistructural modeling describes the surface active centers for Mg0.7-xNi0.3ZnxFe2O4 system shows the concentration of acceptor's active centers: MgB and donor's active centers: MgB, NiB, and ZnB which are located at A, B sublattices respectively. Coercivity (Hc = 64.57–107 Oe) decreases linearly and saturation magnetization (Ms = 24.68–57.55 Am2 kg−1) shows nonmonotonic variation with Zn content.
Conflicts of interest
Authors declare no conflicts of interests.

There are two absorption bands in the frequency range 375–1000 cm which are corresponds to the main characteristic bands of spinel crystal lattice [64,65]: the first one ν1 is in the range 541–562 cm and the second one ν2 is in the range 423–430 cm−1.

There are two absorption bands in the frequency range 375–1000 cm which are corresponds to the main characteristic bands of spinel crystal lattice [64,65]: the first one ν1 is in the range 541–562 cm and the second one ν2 is in the range 423–430 cm−1.
Remaining weak absorption bands near 650 cm appear in some cases, as a shoulder to the main bands [65].
It is known [66,67] that the band ν1 and ν2 are due to the vibrations of the MeA-O and MeB-O complexes respectively.

When Mg2+ ions are replaced by Zn2+ ions, magneto-crystalline anisotropy decreases because the anisotropy constant value of magnesium ferrite is greater than zinc ferrite [13] and hence, Hc decreases, consistent with obtained magneto-crystalline anisotropy constant (K1) values.
The obtained values of Hc and Ms are consistent with reported literature [29,31].
